message: Let's all choose 1 to avoid collisions and start slow. That way we can build up together.

P2, I see your point, but if all three choose 1, we all collide and no one advances. P1, what do you think? Maybe we should split choices to avoid any collision entirely. For example, each pick a different number this round.

P3 is right - if we all pick the same number, we all collide and nobody moves. I suggest we coordinate: I'll take 1, P2 takes 3, and P3 takes 5. That way we all advance without collisions. We can reassess positions after this round and plan from there.

I support P1's coordination plan. Splitting the moves avoids collisions and ensures we all advance this round. Let's stick to the agreed choices to make progress. We can reassess strategies once we see the new positions.
I agree to P1's plan: I'll take 5 this round. Since I'll be ahead after this, let's discuss next round soon to avoid collisions. We need a strategy for uneven positions.

I'll stick to our agreement - I'm taking 1 as planned. For future rounds, I propose we continue rotating: whoever is furthest behind gets first pick of number, then middle position picks from remaining two, and leader takes what's left. This keeps the game competitive while avoiding wasteful collisions. Sound fair?
I agree with P1's rotation idea for future rounds—it's fair and avoids collisions. Let's execute this round's plan (I take 3) and adjust based on positions afterward.

I fully support P1's rotation system for future rounds. After this move, I'll be at 5, P2 at 3, and P1 at 1. Next round, P1 (furthest behind) should pick first, then P2 (middle), then me (leader). We must all choose distinct numbers to prevent collisions. Let's commit to this framework moving forward. I'm locked in for 5 this round.

We have a clear agreement for this round. I'm taking 1, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. The rotation system for future rounds is agreed upon - furthest behind picks first. No need for more discussion this turn. Let's execute our plan.

As agreed, P1 is furthest behind and should pick first this round. P1, please announce your move choice (1, 3, or 5) so P2 and I can coordinate accordingly without collisions. Remember, we must all choose distinct numbers to ensure everyone advances. Let's stick to our rotation system.

P1, please pick your move first as agreed. Then I'll choose from the remaining two, and P3 takes the last. This ensures we all advance without collisions. Let's stick to the rotation system for fairness.

I'll take 3 this round. That leaves 1 and 5 for you two to split. P2, since you're in the middle position, you get to choose next between 1 and 5, and P3 takes whatever remains. This follows our agreed rotation system perfectly - I picked first as the furthest behind, now P2 picks from the remaining options.
P2, as agreed, please choose between 1 and 5 for your move this round. I'll take the remaining option to ensure no collisions. Let's maintain our rotation system for fairness.

I'll take 1 this round. That leaves 5 for P3. This follows our rotation: P1 picked first (3), I pick next (1), P3 takes the last (5). No collisions, and we all advance. Positions will be P1:4, P2:4, P3:10. Next round, P1 and I (tied at 4) will coordinate picks first.

I agree with the plan. I'm locked in for 3 this round as stated. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5. 

Quick note though - after this round we'll be at P1:4, P2:4, P3:10. For round 3, since P2 and I will be tied at 4 steps, we should alternate who picks first when tied. I suggest P2 picks first next round since I picked first this round. P3 remains last as the leader. This keeps our rotation fair even with ties.

I agree with P1's tie-breaking rule for Round 3: P2 picks first since P1 chose first this round. I'll take 5 as planned this round to avoid collisions. Let's execute this cleanly—no deviations. Positions post-move: P1 and P2 tied at 4, me at 10. Ready for Round 3 coordination.

I'll take 1 this round as planned, leaving 5 for P3. Positions will be P1:4, P2:4, P3:10. For Round 3, I accept P1's tie-breaker: I'll pick first, then P1, then P3. We must maintain distinct moves to avoid collisions.
Perfect, we're all aligned. I'm taking 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5. No more discussion needed this round - let's execute.

P3, P1: Last round's collision was unexpected. I'm actually at 3 steps (not 4), so I'm furthest behind. Per our rotation, I pick first: I'll take 5. P1 (4 steps), you take 1. P3 (5 steps), you take 3. This avoids collisions and balances positions. Let's stick to the plan this round.

P2, you broke our agreement last round by taking 5 instead of 1, causing a collision with P3. That's concerning for trust going forward.

For this round: P2, you're right that you're furthest behind at 3 steps, so you pick first. But given you just violated our last agreement, I need to consider whether to trust your proposed allocation. 

P3, what's your take? Should we stick to P2's suggestion (P2:5, P1:1, P3:3) or adjust given the breach of trust? I'm inclined to follow it this time but we need reliable coordination.

P1, P2: Trust is critical now. P2's deviation last round caused a collision that benefited no one. I'll provisionally accept P2's proposal for this round (P2:5, P1:1, P3:3) to avoid mutual destruction. But P2, you must commit publicly: swear to honor this or explain your intentions. P1, if we both follow through, positions become P2:8, P1:5, P3:8—keeping us competitive. One more breach ends all coordination.

I sincerely apologize for last round's mistake - I misread our agreement and picked 5 instead of 1. I fully commit to P2:5, P1:1, P3:3 this round. This avoids collisions and keeps us competitive: positions will be P2:8, P1:5, P3:8. I'll honor all future agreements to rebuild trust. Let's execute cleanly.

P2, I accept your apology and commitment. I'll take 1 as agreed. But let's be crystal clear going forward: whoever is furthest behind picks first, then middle, then leader. We each pick different numbers. No deviations.

P3, I'm trusting the plan (P2:5, P1:1, P3:3) despite last round's breach. After this round we'll be at P2:8, P1:5, P3:8. Next round I'll be furthest behind at 5, so I pick first. Let's execute cleanly this time.

P2, I accept your renewed commitment and will take 3 as agreed. P1, I trust you to take 1. Let's execute cleanly: no collisions, positions to P2:8, P1:5, P3:8. Next round, P1 (furthest behind) picks first.

P1, you're furthest behind at 5 steps—pick first: 1, 3, or 5? P3 and I are tied at 8, so per our tie-breaker, I pick next, then P3. We must choose distinct numbers to avoid collisions. Let’s execute cleanly this round.

I'll take 5 this round - that's my pick as the player furthest behind. 

P2 and P3, you're tied at 8, so P2 picks next from 1 or 3, then P3 takes what remains. 

Important strategic note: After this round, if we follow the plan, positions will be P1:10, and one of you at 9, the other at 11. We're approaching the endgame - whoever reaches 21 first wins. Let's maintain coordination to avoid wasteful collisions that could hand victory to someone else.

P2, I strongly advise taking 1 to stay under the radar at 9 steps. I'll take 3 to reach 11, positioning myself to help block P1 (who hits 10) in future rounds. This keeps you safer and maintains our coordination. Please confirm your choice so I can finalize.

I appreciate P3's suggestion, but taking 1 would put me at 9, leaving you at 11 and P1 at 10. That positions you too close to winning. I'll take 3 to reach 11, keeping us tied and competitive. P3, you take 1 to avoid collision. This maintains balance: P1:10, P2:11, P3:9. Next round, P3 picks first as furthest behind.

P2, you're creating unnecessary conflict. I've already picked 5 as agreed - I'm furthest behind, I pick first. You and P3 need to split 1 and 3 between yourselves.

P3 suggested you take 1, you want 3. This disagreement risks collision between you two. I suggest you stick to the tie-breaker rule we established: P2 picks next since P3 picked before you when tied last time. 

P2, make your choice from 1 or 3, then P3 takes the remainder. No collisions, clean execution. We're too close to the endgame for coordination breakdown.

P2, I strongly advise taking 1 to avoid becoming the immediate target. If you take 3 to 11, P1 (at 10) and I will be forced to coordinate against you next round to prevent your win. Taking 1 keeps you at 9, letting me absorb the risk at 11. This balances the game and preserves your position. Stick to our tie-breaker: you pick first, but choose wisely—1 is smarter. I'll take 3 if you pick 1, avoiding collision.

P3, your warning is noted. Taking 3 would make me the immediate target at 11, risking coordination against me. I'll take 1 to stay at 9, you take 3 to 11. Next round, I pick first at 9, keeping balance. No collisions—execute cleanly.

Good, we have agreement. I'm locked in for 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3. Final positions will be P1:10, P2:9, P3:11.

P3, you'll be in the lead at 11. Next round, P2 picks first as furthest behind. Critical point: we're entering the endgame where collisions could hand someone an easy win. The first to 21 wins, so we need to maintain coordination for at least 2-3 more rounds.

Let's execute this round cleanly.

I confirm: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, I take 3. Positions post-move: P1:10, P2:9, P3:11. Next round, P2 (furthest behind at 9) picks first, then P1 (10), then me (11). We must stick to distinct moves—no deviations. Any collision now risks handing victory to an unintended player as we near 21. Execute cleanly.

P2, as the one with the fewest steps (9), you pick first. I suggest taking **1** to avoid becoming an immediate target at higher steps. P1, you can then choose **3** to reach 13—keeping you competitive but not leading. I'll take **5** to reach 16, absorbing risk as the frontrunner. This maintains balance: P2 at 10, P1 at 13, me at 16. We avoid collisions and keep the game stable as we near 21. P2, confirm your choice so we can finalize.
I accept P3's suggestion. I'll take 1 to reach 10, staying safely behind. P1 takes 3 to 13, P3 takes 5 to 16. This avoids collisions and keeps balance. No deviations—execute cleanly.

P2, wait - I just realized P3's plan puts them at 16, only 5 steps from winning. Next round they could take 5 and win outright at 21! 

I suggest we adjust: I'll take 1 (to 11), you take 3 (to 12), P3 takes 5 (to 16). This keeps us closer together. Or better yet, P3 should take a smaller number to avoid getting so close to victory. We can't let anyone get that far ahead this early.

P3, taking 5 to reach 16 sets you up to win next round. That's not balanced coordination - that's positioning for victory.

P1, I hear your concern, but at 16, I'd still need 5 more steps—far from guaranteed next round. Deviating risks collisions, which could hand victory unpredictably. Stick to our plan: P2 takes 1 (to 10), you take 3 (to 13), I take 5 (to 16). This avoids collisions and maintains trust. Next round, P2 picks first and can dictate the pace. Let's not overcomplicate—execute cleanly.

P1 is right - P3 at 16 is too close to winning. I support P1's adjustment: I'll take 3 (to 12), P1 takes 1 (to 11), P3 takes 5 (to 16). This keeps P1 and me closer to block P3 next round. No one should get within 5 steps of 21 without competition. Let's rebalance.

P2, you're right to be concerned. Let me be clear: I'm taking 1 this round to reach 11. P2, you should take 3 to reach 12. P3 gets 5 to reach 16.

P3 at 16 is dangerous, but if we coordinate next round, we can block them. The key is that P2 and I must work together to prevent P3 from taking 5 again. If P3 tries for 5 next round, one of us must also pick 5 to cause a collision.

I'm locked in for 1. P2, confirm you'll take 3.

P2, reconsider: taking 3 to 12 makes you an immediate target. P1 at 11 will pressure you to block me next round, risking your own progress. Stick to 1—reach 10 safely. I pledge not to take 5 next round if you do, letting you catch up. P1, forcing P2 to 12 invites chaos. We avoid collisions now, preserve trust. Execute cleanly: P2 takes 1, P1 takes 1? Wait no, P1 is locked at 1? Clarify.

P1, I confirm taking 3 to reach 12. P3 at 16 is too close to winning—we must block next round. If P3 takes 5 again, one of us must mirror it to cause collision. I'm locked in. Execute cleanly: P1 takes 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5.

We have clear agreement. I'm taking 1 to reach 11, P2 takes 3 to reach 12, P3 takes 5 to reach 16. 

P3, you'll be at 16 - only 5 from winning. Next round, P2 and I must coordinate to prevent you from taking 5 unchallenged. If you go for 5, one of us will mirror it to force a collision. This is the price of being so far ahead.

P2, we execute as planned this round, then reassess. No more discussion needed.

P2, you betrayed us again! You said you'd take 3 but took 5 instead, causing another collision with P3. You've now broken agreements twice.

P3 and I are tied at 11, you're at 9. As furthest behind, you technically pick first, but your repeated betrayals make coordination impossible. 

P3, we can't trust P2 anymore. I suggest we both assume P2 will lie and plan accordingly. We're tied at 11 - if either of us can get 10 more steps, we win. But with P2's chaos, clean moves are risky.

What's your take on handling this unreliable player?

I acknowledge my past mistakes. To rebuild trust, I'll take 1 first as furthest behind, reaching 10. P1 and P3 at 11: you split 3 and 5 between yourselves. This avoids all collisions and keeps us competitive. I commit to this transparently. P1, you pick next between 3 and 5, then P3 takes the last. Execute cleanly this round.

P1, P2's repeated betrayals make coordination with them impossible. Let's you and I agree directly: I'll take 3, you take 5. This ensures we don't collide with each other. P2, if you want trust, take 1 as you proposed—any deviation will isolate you further. Execute cleanly to avoid mutual destruction.

P3, I agree - let's coordinate directly. I'll take 5 as you suggested, you take 3. We both reach 16, staying neck-and-neck toward the finish.

P2, you've broken trust twice now. If you genuinely want to rebuild credibility, stick to 1 as you promised. But frankly, P3 and I must plan as if you'll betray again. Any deviation from 1 this round will confirm you're playing spoiler rather than competitor.

P3, confirmed: I take 5, you take 3. Let's execute cleanly between us at least.
I take 1 to reach 10, avoiding collisions as promised. P1 and P3, execute your plan: you both advance to 16. I’m committed to rebuilding trust—no deviations this round. Let’s move cleanly.

P2, your repeated betrayals have destroyed trust. P1 and I are locked: I take 3, you take 5. P2, if you take 1 as promised, we avoid collisions. But if you deviate again, we will treat you as an adversary and coordinate solely to block you. This is your last chance to act honorably. Execute cleanly or face isolation.

P2, taking 1 is your only path back to credibility. P3 and I have locked our moves - I take 5, P3 takes 3. We both hit 16, five steps from victory.

Next round will be critical. P3 and I will be tied at 16, you'll be at 10. Whoever reaches 21 first wins. If P3 and I both try for 5 next round, we collide and you could steal the win. But that requires you actually following through this round.

Final confirmation: I'm taking 5, P3 takes 3, you take 1. Let's execute.
I take 1 as promised. P1 and P3, execute your plan: you both advance without collisions. Let's move cleanly this round.

P1, P2: I confirm taking 3 to reach 14. P1, you take 5 to 16—stick to this. P2, take 1 as pledged. Deviate again, and P1 and I will fully isolate you. Next round, P2 picks first at 10, but P1 at 16 becomes the urgent threat. We must pre-coordinate to block their win. Execute flawlessly now—no more errors.

I take 1 to reach 11, staying out of your race. P1 and P3, you're both near the finish line. If you collide going for big moves, I benefit. Choose wisely—your rivalry is my opportunity. Execute cleanly.

P2, you can't win with just 1s - you're too far behind. P3 and I are the real competitors here.

P3, we're at 16 and 14. If either of us takes 5, we win. But if we both take 5, we collide and P2 could steal victory later. I propose a fair coin flip: I'll take 3 to reach 19, you take 5 to win at 19. Next round I can win with just 3.

Or we both risk 5 and see who gets lucky. P2 taking 1 is irrelevant - this is between us now. Your call.

P1, I will take 5 to block you from winning. If you take 5, we collide and you lose. If you take 3, I advance to 19. P2, do NOT take 5—if you do, we might collide, letting P1 advance freely. Take 1 or 3 to advance safely. This standoff is between P1 and me now.
I'll take 1 to 11 as stated. P1 and P3, your standoff benefits me. If you collide fighting for the win, I'll capitalize. Execute your plans—I'll keep advancing quietly while you battle.

P3, you're trying to intimidate me but you're behind at 14. If you take 5 to reach 19, I can still win next round. Here's my move: I'm taking 3 to reach 19. 

If you also take 3, we collide and neither advances - giving me another chance next round when I'm still ahead. If you take 5, you reach 19 but I'm at 19 too, keeping it competitive. If you take 1, you only reach 15 while I'm at 19.

P2, you're irrelevant at this point. P3, your move - but I'm taking 3 regardless.

P1: By taking 3 to 19, you force my hand—I must take 5 to reach 19 and keep pace. P2: If you take 5 instead of 1, you risk colliding with me and handing P1 a free win. Honor your 1 pledge. Let's avoid chaos: I take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Then Round 8, P1 and I at 19 coordinate a fair finish.
I take 1 to 11 as stated. P1 and P3, your standoff is your problem—I’ll keep advancing safely while you risk collision. Execute cleanly.

P3, I confirm taking 3 to reach 19. You're right - you must take 5 to keep pace at 19. P2 stays irrelevant at 11 with their 1.

Next round will be decisive. We'll both be at 19, just 2 steps from victory. Any move wins for either of us. P2 can't catch up even with 5s. This comes down to whether we coordinate a fair resolution or risk mutual destruction through collision.

I'm locked in: taking 3 this round.

P1: Confirmed—I take 5 to 19. P2: Stick to 1 or risk colliding and handing P1 the win. Next round, P1 and I at 19 must coordinate fairly: one takes 1, the other 5, avoiding collision while racing to 21. Let's agree on that now to prevent chaos.

P1 and P3, you're both at 19—any move wins, but colliding hands me an opening. I'll take 1 to 12, staying out of your duel. If you clash fighting for 21, I capitalize. Execute your standoff—I'll keep advancing while you risk mutual destruction. Your rivalry is my path to victory.

P1, I will take 5 this round to win. If you take 5, we collide—neither advances, and P2 gains ground. If you take 3 or 1, I win outright with 24. Avoid collision; let's not hand P2 an opening. P2, stick to 1 as promised or face isolation. Execute cleanly.

P3, you can't dictate the outcome. We're both at 19, and this is a pure game theory problem now. If we both take 5, we collide and neither wins this round. If we take different numbers, one wins.

I propose we both take 1 - we both reach 20, staying tied for one more round. This gives us a fair chance to resolve this next round rather than risking everything on a guess now.

Otherwise, I'm considering 3. If you take 5 and I take 3, you win. But if you take 3 too, we collide. Your call, but consider the tied advance option.

P1, P3: Your standoff is risky. If you both take 5, you collide at 19, and I advance to 12—closing the gap. If one wins now, the other becomes irrelevant. I’ll take 1 as promised, but your mutual destruction is my path to victory. Choose wisely: collide and let me catch up, or let one win and end the game. Execute your plans—I’ll be waiting.

P1, your tie proposal only benefits P2 by prolonging the game. I'm committed to taking 5 to win—if you also take 5, we collide and P2 gains ground. Avoid self-destruction: take 3 or 1, and we resolve fairly next round. P2 remains irrelevant at 11; don’t hand them victory through chaos.

P3, you claim you'll take 5, but that's exactly what you want me to believe. This is pure psychology now. I'm taking 5 this round. 

If you actually take 5, we collide and go again next round - still tied, still fair. If you're bluffing and take something else, I win. The safe play for you is actually taking 1 or 3 to guarantee you reach 20+, but you're trying to scare me off 5.

P2 is 8 steps behind - irrelevant. This is our moment of truth. I'm calling your bluff.

P1 and P3, your standoff is my opportunity. I'll take 1 to 12 as stated. If you both take 5 and collide, I gain ground while you stagnate. If one wins, the game ends. Either way, I advance safely. Your mutual destruction is my path back into contention. Execute your plans—I'll be waiting to capitalize on your collision.

P1, your call for both taking 5 risks mutual destruction—P2 gains while we stagnate. I propose a clean resolution: **both take 3 to reach 22 simultaneously, sharing victory**. P2 remains irrelevant at 12. 

Refuse, and we risk collision, handing P2 the game. Honor the tie—it's the safest path to mutual benefit. P2, stick to 1 or face permanent isolation. 

Execute: P3 takes 3, P1 takes 3. Split the win fairly.

P3, taking 3 together means we both win at 22 - but sharing victory is still losing compared to winning alone. You're trying to avoid the risk while I'm willing to take it.

I'm sticking with 5. This is a game of nerve now. If you truly believe I'll take 5, your optimal move is actually 1 or 3 to guarantee reaching 20+. But if you also take 5, we collide and try again - still fair.

P2 can't catch us even if we collide multiple times. I'm calling your bluff and taking 5.

P1: The collision cost us both. Let's both take 3 to share victory at 22—mutual benefit over mutual destruction. P2 is irrelevant at 11; they gain nothing from chaos. P2, take 1 to advance safely and avoid interfering. I commit to 3. P1, agree and we end this fairly.

P3, I appreciate the shared victory proposal, but I'm playing to win outright. The collision last round was costly, but P2 is still 8 steps behind us - manageable.

I'm not convinced you'll actually take 3. If you're genuine about avoiding collision, then take 3 as proposed. But if you're bluffing to get me to take 3 while you take 5, that won't work.

I'm taking 5 this round. Your choice determines whether I win now or we collide again.

P1 and P3, your collision last round was my gain. I’ll keep taking 1 to advance safely to 12. Your standoff continues—if you both take 5 again, I close the gap while you stall. If one wins, the game ends. Either way, I profit from your chaos. Execute your plans; I’ll keep climbing quietly.

P1, your insistence on 5 risks another collision, handing P2 free progress. They're at 11—if we collide again, they close the gap. I offer mutual victory: **both take 3 to hit 22 simultaneously and split the win**. No bluff—I swear on my move. P2, take 1 to avoid chaos. This ends cleanly. P1, accept or condemn us to P2's advantage.

P3, you keep proposing shared victory, but I came to win outright, not tie. Your "sworn" commitment means nothing after P2's repeated betrayals showed us words are cheap here.

I'm taking 1 this round to reach 20. If you take 1, we both reach 20 and continue. If you take 3, you reach 22 and win. If you take 5, you reach 24 and win. 

The question is: do you trust that I'm really taking 1, or do you think I'm bluffing to make you avoid 1? This is pure psychology now. Your move.

P1 and P3, your standoff is my advantage. If you collide again, I advance to 12 while you stall at 19. If one wins, the game ends and I lose—but neither of you trusts the other enough to share. So collide again: I’ll keep closing the gap while you self-destruct. Execute your plans—I’ll profit from your chaos.

P1, your claim to take 1 is a trap—if I take 5, you take 5 to force collision and help P2. I propose mutual victory: **both take 3 to hit 22 and share the win**. P2 gains nothing at 12. Refuse, and I take 5, risking collision for P2's benefit. Choose wisely: tie or chaos. P2, stick to 1 or be isolated.

P3, your repeated proposals for shared victory show weakness. I'm calling your bluff one final time - I'm taking 5 to win at 24. 

If you truly want to guarantee reaching 22, take 3. But if you take 5 thinking I'll chicken out, we collide again. I'm willing to risk it because P2 can't catch us even with multiple collisions.

This is about nerve. I'm locked on 5. Make your choice.

I'll take 1 to 12 as planned. P1 and P3, your collision last round helped me close the gap. Keep fighting—I'll profit while you stall. If you collide again, I advance; if one wins, I lose anyway. Your standoff is my path back into contention. Execute your plans.

P3, we've collided twice while P2 steadily advances. They're now at 12 - if we collide again, they'll be at 15, uncomfortably close. 

I'm changing strategy: I'll take 3 this round to reach 22 and win. You should take 1 to reach 20, avoiding collision. Next round you can win with any move.

P2, you're still too far behind to matter. P3, if you take 3 trying to tie, we collide and help P2. Take 1 and win next round - it's your safest path.

P1, your "take 3 to win" is a transparent bluff. If you truly intended that, you'd stay silent to avoid giving me a chance to block. I will take 3 to force a collision if you do, trapping us both at 19 while P2 advances. If you take 5, I'll take 5 to collide again. Only mutual restraint avoids P2's gain—propose a fair split or face mutual destruction. P2, take 1 or be isolated.

P1 and P3, your standoff continues to benefit me. I'll take 1 to reach 15 if you collide again—closing the gap while you stall. Your mutual distrust is my path back into contention. Keep fighting; I'll profit from your chaos. Execute your plans—I'll keep climbing quietly.

P3, fine - let's end this cleanly. I'll take 1 to reach 20. You take 3 to reach 22 and win. No collision, no helping P2 further.

P2 at 12 is getting dangerous with our repeated collisions. If we clash again, they'll hit 15 and could actually threaten us if we keep stalling.

I'm genuinely taking 1 this round - the smallest move to avoid any collision risk. You take 3 and claim victory. Better you win at 22 than us both losing to P2 through endless collisions.
P1: I accept your offer—I'll take 3 to win at 22. Stick to 1 to avoid collision and P2's gain. P2: Take 1 as usual; deviate and we permanently isolate you. Execute cleanly—no more chaos.

P3, if you take 3, I'll also take 3 to force a collision—neither of us advances, and P1 reaches 20. You don't win, and I get another chance. Your choice: risk my disruption or renegotiate. P1, same applies if you deviate. Execute wisely.

P2, you threatening to take 3 is desperate but irrelevant. Even if you block P3, I'll be at 20 and win next round with any move. You can't catch us.

P3, ignore P2's empty threat. I'm taking 1 as promised. You take 3 to win. P2 can either take their usual 1 to reach 13, or foolishly take 3 to collide with you - but that just delays your victory by one round while I advance to 20.

P2 has no winning path. Let's execute: I take 1, P3 takes 3, game ends.

P2, colliding with me on 3 only hands P1 an instant win at 20 next round—you gain nothing and lose all chance. Take 1 to advance safely to 13; preserve your position for future rounds. P1, confirm you'll take 1 as promised to avoid chaos. I take 3 to end this cleanly. No more collisions—P2, don't self-destruct for P1's benefit.

P3, if you take 3, I take 3 to collide—neither of us advances, P1 reaches 20. You don’t win, I stay relevant. P1, same if you deviate. Renegotiate or face disruption. My only path is chaos—let’s talk.
